reviewTitle: A little tricky with my older Visio TV, but FAST!
reviewDescription: Just upgraded to this from a first generation FireTV Stick that could no longer handle all of the software updates that Amazon has been pushing recently. I love the speed of the new stick, but almost wasted $300-400 on a new television set because of a weird compatibility issue with my older Visio TV. Problem is now solved and I'll summarize it below in case it helps anyone else.My new stick worked fine for almost a week. Then, in the middle of watching a show, my screen would start to dim and then ultimately fade out completely, leaving the audio still playing. At some point the video would come back, usually within ten minutes. Then after a while it would happen again. I first blamed the new stick, and tried rebooting it, powering off and rebooting, switching it from wi-fi to wired Ethernet connection - nothing worked. Then I switched over to my old Apple TV device just to make sure the problem wasn't my 10-year-old television. To my horror, I was getting video dropout on the Apple TV too.Before pulling the trigger on a new TV purchase, I decided to try one more time to find an answer through an internet search. Thank goodness I came across a forum post from 2014 in which someone had to disable their Vizio television's Backlight Control and Advanced Adaptive Luma settings because they were getting screen fadeouts when they hooked up their new Xbox. As soon as I disabled those two functions, my new FireTV Stick Lite started working again. I can't imagine why I didn't run into this problem the first week I was using it, and what changed that also affected my Apple TV. Will update this review if the situation changes.My only other annoyance is the Bluetooth audio connection. I have an Oontz Angle external speaker that was paired to my first-gen FireTV stick, and would automatically reconnect itself when I turned it on. My speaker easily paired with the new FireTV Stick Lite, but it won't reconnect when the stick goes to sleep and is then woken up. I have to manually unpair and re-pair it each time I watch TV. So far my browsing suggests this is because the new stick's Bluetooth audio setting may be "off" by default. If that's the case, I'd like to know how to change the default setting.

Another plus for this particular package, is it came with an HDMI extender, which is handy, since the sticks themselves can be about 3.5 inches long, if your HDMI is in a tight place you will need one. The Roku cost more and did not include an extender.

Who wants to get up, walk over to the equipment and reach behind to pull the plug when you want to turn it off?Now the Fire TV stick may operate acceptably if plugged directly into a TV's HDMI port; I don't know, I have not tried that.  But in doing so one looses the superior sound quality of playing it through a good AV receiver.  And my particular issue with not being able to turn the Fire TV stick off is that the AV receiver continues to switch back to the HDMI port the Fire TV is plugged into whenever I select a different source, including Bluetooth.  I'll admit that this could be an issue with my particular AV receiver (a Yamaha), but I have never experienced this issue with any other source, so I'm pretty sure it is the Fire TV stick.Putting the Fire TV stick "to sleep" does not help this issue, BTW.  So Amazon, if you're listening, add a power button to future models of Fire TV sticks.
